description: From Middle English distingwen, from Old French distinguer, from Latin distinguere (“to separate, divide, distinguish, set off, adorn, literally mark off”), from di-, dis- (“apart”) + stinguere. Compare extinguish.

verbs.description: distinguish (third-person singular simple present distinguishes, present participle distinguishing, simple past and past participle distinguished)

entries.meaning: To recognize someone or something as different from others based on its characteristics.
examples: Synonyms: differentiate, discriminate; see also Thesaurus:tell apart

entries.meaning: To see someone or something clearly or distinctly.
To make oneself noticeably different or better from others through accomplishments.
examples: The soldier distinguished himself in combat and received a medal.
The soldier was distinguished with a medal for his bravery.
